node.text:
Pull > stand through independent step play ideas with @kozycouch 

*Reminder - many of these can be done with a couch cushion or crib mattress too! 

+Pull to stand with hand support - place the toys on the elevated surface and you can gently encourage the half kneel transition! 
+Sit to stand with no hands - use your legs as a surface to encourage the partial squat, and let them stand from there! 
+Independent standing - no hands, but back support. This is a great way for little one’s that really dislike someone physically helping them - it allows the independent weight shift which often leads to a step
+Weight shifting with and without hand support. Giving them a toy to hold from this position is an AWESOME way to encourage weight shifting and eventually the independent step towards you! 
+Pull > stand on a vertical surface (meaning very little hand support, which makes it MUCH more challenging!) 
+Cruising on a vertical surface (ran out of room to add this one - but think same set up, but encouraging them to weight shift and side step)

Hope that helps! Let me know if you’ve tried these, and tag a parent that could use these tips! And .. if you’re still struggling with setting the environment up for these skills, WALKING masterclass (link in bio) has tons more tips!

node.text:
***Rookie mistake 😵‍💫 to see the whole video without the bottom cut off, make sure you watch IN REELS!***

Sitting through crawling @kozycouch ideas! And remember, a couch cushion or crib mattress work for these too! 

+Active trunk rotation set up, which leads into…..
+In/out sit transitions, which leads into….
+Modified hands & knees positioning - HUGE for core, hip & shoulder strengthening in prep for crawling…
+Tall & Short kneeling - HUGE for booty & hip work - helloooo strength for the upcoming milestones! 

+Army crawling —> regular crawling set ups. If your little one is army crawling but not yet up on hands and knees, giving this a shot with environment set ups often helps! 

Hope those help! stay tuned for pre-walking to steps ideas tomorrow, and don’t forget, through Saturday you can save 5% with code KC5 on @kozycouch (except pebble!).

node.text:
Play ideas from tummy time to rolling to sitting for use with the @kozycouch ! 

I’ve teamed up with them to share some ideas for motor use through the first 3 years, and I’m so excited for this one! With all of these, modify as needed for your little and provide whatever support they need! 

And if you DONT have a Kozy couch, couch cushions or crib mattresses are alternatives to practice these same skills! 

Here’s some ideas for the first 6ish months: 

+supported vertical play & chin tuck practice- awesome for encouraging vision, strengthening the neck muscles & working towards the 3-4 month chin tuck!

+vertical tummy time- can be done at all different angles & is amazing for increasing comfort during TT as you work towards flat on the floor 

+rolling practice up & down- I’d wait until 4 months or so to start this one, but it’s AWESOME for activating abs and working towards rolling skills! 

+Supported sitting (forward or backward facing)- awesome for little ones that may be throwing themselves backwards or flopping forward in sitting 🙌

+supported sidelying- straight up if they need more support, or reclined to work those abs and encourage a back to belly roll! 

So, have you tried any of these, or do you plan to!? 

Stay tuned for lots more tips over the next few days for different age groups, and now through Saturday you can use code KC5 for 5% off your very own @kozycouch (all colors EXCEPT pebble) 🤍🙌

node.text:
According to the AAP, for children under two years of age - falls out of cribs, bassinets & playpens are one of the leading causes for emergency room visits and musculoskeletal injuries, most often to the head and neck. 😩 

Many, many times, this is related to children performing a motor skill that results in a risk - like getting into sitting, pulling to stand, or attempting to climb out of the crib.

Before I go on, the most important take away from this reel should be to drop the crib to the lowest possible setting as soon as you’re able, BEFORE you see motor skills. 

So let’s talk further…

The really amazing things about babies & sleep is that often times, babies practice motor skills in their sleep well before they do them on the floor. 

There’s no definitive information on WHY motor skills happen first in their sleep/cribs, and THEN on the floor, but from a motor development standpoint, I believe it’s because a softer surface (like a crib mattress), allows for easier execution of tasks than a harder surface like the floor. I can’t tell you how many times I’ve heard “I’ve never seen them do it, and all of a sudden I looked at the monitor and they were sitting up in bed.” 

While practicing motor skills in the crib & during sleep is both good (they’re doing it, so exciting!) & bad (hello sleepless nights while skills emerge 😩) - it absolutely poses a risk. BUT the good thing is that it’s a risk we can often mitigate with increased education about potential crib hazards. 

First- check your crib manuals for the MAXIMUM height information. Second, my recommendation is to drop the crib to the lowest possible setting BEFORE you see new motor skills emerge.

As with anything, you know your baby best - this is a general recommendation but there will always be determined danger babies that still figure out some way to possibly get into a dicey situation - in which case, you might have to brainstorm! 

If you have any tips that were helpful in your situation, please share them below! Hope this helps 🤍

node.text:
With back to school in full swing for many kids, here’s my top 5 tips for backpack use & promoting optimal posture! 

1- place the heaviest items CLOSEST to their back. This offsets the load & makes it easier for them to stay upright while not being pulled backwards/adding stress to the shoulders & spine!

2- use both straps! It evens out weight distribution and again, helps promote symmetrical, upright posture. 

3- snug it up! Tighten the straps as much as comfortably possible to keep the backpack tight to their body, which takes stress off the shoulders and upper back. 

4- put as little as possible into the backpack. If it’s feasible to leave certain books at home or at school that are heavier, do that! 

5-try to find one that is similar to their size- meaning if you have a pre-schooler or younger elementary school child, try to find a slightly smaller backpack that still fits what is needed. I’ve had luck with searching “toddler backpack”, rather than buying a full size one!

Hope that helps! 🎒🎒

node.text:
Rolling is pretty cool because it is often the first clear, tangible milestone we see! From a textbook standpoint, belly to back rolling occurs first (often between the 3-5 month mark as an intentional skill), followed by back to belly (often between the 4-6 month mark). Disclaimer - back to belly is occasionally seen first now for a few reasons, and if that’s the case for your little one, please know that’s okay! 

The cool thing about rolling is that before it’s an intentional skill, it’s often an UNINTENTIONAL roll caused by the weight of the head and not yet developed balance between the muscles on the front and back of the body. 
Often times, parents will see a very early, uncontrolled roll like the first clip in this reel…then it goes away (which often makes parents so nervous!) and then re-emerges as an intentional, controlled roll like in clip 3. 

This reel shows that progression - 

First- unintentional & uncontrolled, again, led by the weight of the head with no balance of musculature yet to counteract the roll —> then it progresses into the second clip - a little more controlled but still initiated by the head, and the rest of the body follows —> then the third clip - weight shifting, pivoting on the belly, pressing up onto hands & maybe even reaching for toys creates an intentional, controlled roll —> then lastly, the balance between the muscles on the front & back of the body that occurs as a child plays & gets stronger leads to pre-crawling skills like seen here - pressing up onto forearms & hands, weight shifting, playing between the back & side, and maybe even attempts at movement forward, backwards, or sideways. 

This is where toy placement & environment set up are HUGE! Imagine - for clips 3 & 4, placing toys a little above eye level and/or around them in a circle. Giving them incentive to explore & figure out how to get what they want can be the catalyst for these progressions, and make what seems like “just laying around” become intentional & purposeful play! 

So did you see this progression with your little one?! Drop any questions below & remember- ROLL class (link in bio) has all the tips you need to get your LO rolling 🤍

node.text:
Torticollis tips for older kids! How to use play to lengthen & strengthen, especially in older kids….

Here’s the thing with torticollis- a tight muscle is a weak muscle. So once you gain a little LENGTH, you then need to create STRENGTH in the new range of motion. Torticollis also is not JUST about the neck, and even though it’s easy to get caught up in that area because it’s what we visibly see as a “problem”, the rest of the body being addressed is crucial for success. A nice continuation of how confusing torticollis can be, amiright 😵‍💫

But let’s simplify it! Try this activity. This brings in the natural righting reactions in the head and trunk, and helps target the areas we want to target when it comes to torticollis treatment. 

The nice thing about this activity is that you can do it on BOTH sides (because it’s lengthening & strengthening), it brings the trunk & hips in (when adding something to grab), AND as you can see- it’s fun! 

Hope that helps- drop your questions below & tag a parent that could use these tips! 🤍

node.text:
Check this reel out for some torticollis tips! 

Reminder, if you think your child has torticollis, please be sure to mention it to their pediatrician. These activities can be performed to both sides, whether a torticollis present or not, and are great ways to encourage a neutral head position & equal strength on both sides of the neck. See previous posts & TORTICOLLIS highlight for more!

Activities: 
+gently kiss your little one to encourage a stretch to the opposite side. 

+position all toys on the non-preferred side. Encourage them to turn just their head and engage with toys. Tip- gently anchor their chest like shown to ensure the rotation is coming only from their head, not their whole trunk. Let them actively turn to the toys- don’t force their head over! 

+rotate what side of the crib their head is on. Babies will naturally turn towards the door, so rotating their head position will encourage turning in both directions.

+see previous post for football carry 

+encourage righting reactions and neck strengthening/stretching by gently tilting side to side (best for 4-5+ months when righting reactions begin to emerge for many babes). With torticollis- you’ll see that one side has much less of a reaction when tipped. We want to see the reactions be equal, so pulling in the gentle kissing or football carry can be a great idea if you’re noticing differences! 

Hope that helps- drop your questions below & tag a parent that could use this info!

node.text:
The football carry! 

First- as with everything I share, if you think your child may have torticollis or you have any specific concerns about their development, please be sure to bring those concerns to your pediatrician. This is not individualized medical advice and should not replace assessment by your medical team. See START HERE highlight for more specifics! 

One of the reasons I love this carry so much is that not only is it fantastic for gently stretching the neck muscles (specifically the ones we want to elongate when torticollis is present), but it also brings in a nice change to the vestibular input your little one receives, and can also help alleviate belly discomfort if that’s a struggle! 

There is also no harm in carrying this way from day one, whether torticollis is present or not, as long as you’re fully supporting them and ensuring they’re secure in your arms! 

So, how do you do it? The big thing to understand with torticollis is as mentioned in the last two posts, there is a usually two components. A tilt to the SAME side as the tight muscle and a rotation to the OPPOSITE. Addressing those components separately is key! 

To do the football carry, have your baby’s cheek against your for arm. Their arm should not be resting above your for arm, or it will negate the stretch! Having their check rest against your forearm will create space between their ear and shoulder, and elongate the muscles that would be tight with torticollis. This carry should be comfortable, tears or fussing shouldn’t be present! If they’re not loving it, try carrying them more vertically, and easing into sidelying as they settle. 

More detailed overview is in my TORTICOLLIS highlight, specifically in regards to figuring out which cheek should test against your forearm. If there is a right tilt, right cheek should be against right forearm. Switch for a left tilt. 

Hope this helps! Stay tuned for more tips over the next few days on gently addressing the tilt and rotation characteristic of torticollis. Drop your questions below and tag a parent that could use this info!

*alt text pinned in comments!

node.text:
Let’s talk torticollis & asymmetry! 

This video is a really quick example of what *can* happen with torticollis in regards to development of asymmetries in motor milestones. 

Now - this is not always the case!!! There are times that torticollis is truly just a musculoskeletal issue that needs to be addressed, and it will resolve without the development of asymmetries or delays in milestones. 

BUT, there are also times that asymmetries being present are one of the first things noted - things like parents seeing their child only looking in one direction, strongly preferring to use one hand, or roll in one direction, etc. These asymmetries can and often do impact the development of motor milestones, and absolutely need to be addressed in order to prevent further difficulty.

In this video- you can imagine that if a baby is in the characteristic position of torticollis (head tilted in one direction and rotated to the opposite- see previous post if you’re not sure what I mean), that can lead to them looking only in one direction, seeing one hand much more than the other - which can lead to reaching more with that hand. If they are reaching and grabbing one foot more than the other, that can lead to happy baby to one side, ultimate rolling to one side from back to belly, and if on their belly the entire weight of their head is shifted off center, we can often see rolling from belly to back in only one direction as well! 

So, what do you do if you’re noticing asymmetries or the classic torticollis presentation? 

First, definitely speak to your pediatrician and discuss whether a PT evaluation is warranted! It is often ideal to have it assessed if torticollis is suspected - that’ll  help determine the best course of treatment (whether its at home stretches and positioning or actual skilled PT interventions) and help guide you to the best care for your little one!

Second, stay tuned…I’ll be sharing lots of tips and tricks in posts on environment set up to encourage equal movement, gentle carrying techniques, and lots more! 

Drop your questions regarding torticollis & asymmetries below, and check out my TORTICOLLIS highlight for more in depth information.

node.text:
Let’s talk torticollis!⠀
⠀
Torticollis refers to restriction in the sternocleidomastoid muscle (SCM) in the neck. Although it often involves more than just this muscle- by definition, that’s the trouble spot!⠀
If you put your hand on the RIGHT side of your neck, bring your RIGHT ear closer to your RIGHT shoulder, & then turn your head toward the LEFT, you will feel that muscle bulge. If you were sort of “stuck” in this position, that would be considered a RIGHT torticollis. ⠀
⠀
So, the PRIMARY (but not only) muscle responsible for torticollis causes a tilt in the SAME direction as the tight muscle & a rotation in the OPPOSITE.⠀
⠀
Nice & confusing, amiright? 🤪🥴⠀
⠀
So, torticollis can occur in utero (often the case) or after birth, especially in the first 3-4 months of life when little ones are reliant on us for positioning - meaning where we place them, they stay. ⠀
⠀
Often times, the first signs of torticollis are a parent saying “my child loves to look one way”, or “my child always wants to turn to the....”, or noticing that your child’s head is always tilted to one side in pictures, etc. ⠀
⠀
More significant signs can include asymmetries in the face, flattening of the back of the skull on one side, neck & trunk tightness, limited range of motion or ability to track in one direction, only bringing one hand to their mouth, only rolling in one direction, or even curving of their trunk toward one side. Again, in general, It is often very subtle at first!⠀
⠀
Now … here’s the thing, please don’t panic. I want to share this information with you because torticollis is common, often goes unnoticed until it’s worse, and can impact many milestones, BUT in many cases, it can be managed with conservative treatment & the earlier the better for beginning treatment! My hope with this info is to empower you and provide the tools to notice something may be up, and trust your instinct to bring those concerns to your ped to discuss if further evaluation is warranted. ⠀
⠀
So, as this series progresses, I’ll be sharing lots more info & tips, but for now, drop any torticollis questions you want covered below, and tag a parent that could use this info!

*alt-text in comment
